Description: Wheel-made pottery oil-lamp with a low body, a central point and a wide overhanging rim that slopes in towards the centre. The nozzle is broken and lost. Possibly traces of black slip or resin residue. Red-brown fabric.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Similar form from Athens (Howland 1958, no. 94, but see also no.156), parallels from Tocra and South Ionia (Bailey 1975, 1989-9). Bailey suggested a similar piece may have been made in Naukratis (Bailey 1975, 198), however an East Greece origin seems more likely. Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals, Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.23) (Phase 3)
